author: Will Friedwald
title: From Budapest to Broadway
text:
Stephen Sondheim’s famous one-sentence appraisal of Rodgers and Hammerstein’s first two collaborations—“‘Oklahoma!’ is about a picnic, ‘Carousel’ is about life and death”—is only partly true. The power of “Carousel,” whose latest Broadway revival opens this week, is that it’s both things at once, encompassing not only life and death but a “real nice clambake.”

When the Theater Guild first proposed in 1943 that composer Richard Rodgers and lyricist Oscar Hammerstein II turn Ferenc Molnár’s “Liliom” into a musical, Rodgers...
